EagleHawk Field Services LLC
Hawkville Gas Treating Facility
Risk Management Plan


Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

EagleHawk Field Services LLC (EagleHawk) has a standing commitment to worker and public safety, demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention.  These resources include safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the process at the Hawkville Gas Treating Facility (Hawvkille or the Facility) and training of operations personnel and contractors.  EagleHawk implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  EagleHawk places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspections and regularly training responsible personnel.  Should a release occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release, and prevent or mitigate any off-site consequences.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Hawkville, located in La Salle County, Texas, is owned by EagleHawk.  Hawkville is a natural gas processing plant comprised of natural gas liquid recovery, natural gas liquids fractionation, and natural gas treatment and compression equipment.  The natural gas liquid recovery equipment is designed to recover natural gas liquids from the inlet gas.  Produced gas and liquids are delivered to the facility from gathering systems and pipelines.  The Facility process produces natural gas, natural gas liquids, and stabilized condensate.  The Facility equipment operates to separate, stabilize, treat (as necessary to remove hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide), compress (gas), dehydrate (gas), store (natural gas liquids and stabilized condensate), and transfer gas, natural gas liquids, and stabilized condensate to sales.  Natural gas is transported by pipeline from the Facility, and natural gas liquids and stabilized condensat

e are transported by cargo tank motor vehicles.

The listed flammable substance above the threshold quantities at Hawkville is a flammable mixture containing methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane and pentane.  No toxic substances are present in the process.  The Facility complies with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements and Program 1 requirements of the U.S. EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Risk Management Program (RMP). 

General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

Implementation of appropriate administrative and technological safeguards in the process ensures the safety of workers and the surrounding community.  The Hawkville process has been designed using current equipment design codes and standards with appropriate safety controls.  The process design includes control systems to maintain operating parameters, such as temperature, pressures, flow, and level within allowable limits.  Written operating procedures for the process are developed, maintained, and periodically reviewed for safe operations.  Personnel operating the process are trained on the operating procedures to familiarize them with the consequences of exceeding allowable safety and operability limits and steps to correct deviation from normal operating parameters.  Additionally, EagleHawk has developed maintenance procedures to maintain equipment integrity.   

EagleHawk has implemented safe work practices to help ensure worker and process safety at Hawkville.  Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel; (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened; (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work); and (5) a permit and procedure to

ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures, along with training of involved personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.
	
	
Specific Prevention Steps

Hazards in the process at Hawkville are continually managed to ensure safe operations.  The accident prevention program is applied throughout the RMP covered process at Hawkville and covers all individually listed flammable substances and regulated flammable mixtures.  The prevention program is designed and implemented to prevent accidental releases that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors.  Safety features are incorporated into the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of Hawkville to help prevent, quickly detect, and control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process: 

Release Containment and Control

Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and combust releases.
Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).
Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters. 
Containment areas to contain liquid releases.
Dual mechanical seals on hydrocarbon liquid pumps, where feasible. 
Total plant emergency shutdown (ESD) system.

Release Mitigation

Portable fire extinguishers. 
Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures.
Personal protective equipment.

Five Year Accident History

EagleHawk has an excellent record of accident prevention at the Facility.  There have been no large or small accidental releases resulting in injuries to site personnel or contractors, or in offsite consequences. 

Emergency Response Program Information

EagleHawk maintains written emergency procedures at the Facility to protect worker and public safety and the environment.  These include procedures for a fire or explosion and notification o

f local emergency response agencies in the event of an accidental release.  Employees are trained on the emergency procedures and the procedures are updated as needed when the process or Facility is modified.  Changes to the emergency procedures are administered through the Management of Change process.

The overall emergency program for Hawkville is coordinated with the La Salle County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Coordination includes periodic meetings to communicate the Facility operations, contact information, and response activities.  EagleHawk has 24/7 communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., La Salle County LEPC Chairman, La Salle County Sheriff and Cotulla Fire Department).  The LEPC would assist the Facility, as requested, to notify the public, control traffic, and facilitate response to an incident.  EagleHawk provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated flammable substances in the Facility.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

EagleHawk tracks and resolves all process hazard analysis recommendations.  All personnel, employees, and contractors are encouraged to notify their supervisor of any changes or modifications to the Facility that could result in improved safety.  Plans to improve safety include:  1)  Installation of additional process controls, such as tank gauges and/or alarms; and 2)  Installation of process area detection systems.
